results.title: Brimbank beat
results.brief_description:
In 2004, Brimbank City Council secured funding from Arts Victoria to engage an artist to work with local residents, from diverse locales, ages and backgrounds, to produce a compelling historical and contemporary sweep of life across the municipality. Artist Angela Bailey began work on the project in mid 2004. Angela worked closely with a host of contributors to collect stories , photos and moving images that provide vignettes of the local characters, cultures, interests and passions that drive the Brimbank heart beat. The Brimbank Beat CD-Rom is the result of this endeavour but there are other less tangible outcomes. Friendships were formed along the way and here, in this compilation of disparate interests and backgrounds emerges a single municipality called Brimbank.
The historical film footage that is featured on Brimbank beat is from a film by the Victorian filmmaker John Henry Jackson.

results.title: Brilliant lies
results.brief_description: Not since ‘Disclosure’ have sexual games been so dirty. Based on David Williamson’s play of the same name it is the story of Susie O’Connor (Gia Carides), who says that from the moment she started working for him, her boss sexually harassed her. When she didn’t submit to his advances, she was sacked. She sues her boss (Anthony LaPaglia) for compensation - but he claims he never touched her and she made it all up. The challenge when watching this highly stylised movie is to determine who is telling the truth and who is telling brilliant lies.

results.title: Brilliant gardens
results.creator_credit: Nigel Farrell, Tadpole Lane and Botanical Gardens Conservation International
results.brief_description: Let Rula Lenska lead you on a magical journey through 8 beautiful botanic gardens in Britain from places such as Kew, Edinburgh, Cambridge, Chelsea, Westonbirt, Glasgow, Ness and Wisley. The individual, and often international species found in each garden are explored, as well as what they say about the social, political and horticultural tendencies of the country.

results.title: Brighton rock = Young scareface. Eight o'clock walk
results.creator_credit: Lance Comfort, John Boulting, George King, Roy Boulting, British Lion Corporation and Associated British Picture Corporation
results.brief_description: A double bill feature. “Brighton Rock” written by Graham Greene is a post-war thriller starring Richard Attenborough as Pinkie, a hoodlum. Pinkie marries a young waitress as his alibi for murder, then tries to get rid of her and a rival gang intervenes. “Eight O’clock walk” once again stars Attenborough in the title role as a taxi driver falsely accused of the murder of a little girl and his struggle with his wife to prove his innocence. A courtroom drama with excellent performances.

results.title: Bright lights, big city
results.creator_credit: James Bridges, Sydney Pollack, Mark Rosenberg and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: When his model wife, Amanda (Phoebe Cates) leaves him, aspiring writer Jamie Conway (Michael J. Fox) plunges into a downward spiral of drugs and alcohol on the Manhattan nightclub scene, ably assisted by his sleazy, yuppie friend Allagash (Kiefer Sutherland). Providing some sort of continuity to dreary days en route to nightly excess is the tabloid story of the plight of a coma baby which parallels Jamie’s fragile existence since his mother died and Amanda left him. With the help of Allagash’s cousin (Michael J. Fox’s wife, Tracy Pollan), a persistent younger brother (Charlie Schlatter), and a well meaning colleague (Swoosie Kurtz), there may be hope for Jamie’s salvation. “Bright lights, big city” is one of Fox’s few attempts to break his comic/Mr Nice Guy persona (“Casualties of war” being another example), and did so to mixed receptions. Based on the book by Jay McInerney.

images.caption: Bright lights, big city (James Bridges) still

results.title: Bright future...for some
results.brief_description: Third in a series of nine animated films on the history of Western Civilization. Examines the merchants’ reactions when they had to pay road, bridge, market and money exchange tolls to local landlords after riches began pouring in from Europe. Shows how they plotted with the king to stop this “exploitation” and were subsequently successful in having new laws passed in their favour, to the detriment of the peasants and craftsmen. Suitable for lower secondary level.

results.title: Brigadoon
results.brief_description: The magical world of Brigadoon casts a spell in this exuberant Scottish village that rises out of the Highland mists for just one day in every century. Gene Kelly and Van Johnson star as two jaded New Yorkers who come to Scotland on a hunting expedition and stumble upon the elusive 18th century village. There Kelly falls in love with Brigadoon’s prettiest lass, Fiona, played by Cyd Charisse, and he must decide whether to stay with her forever or return to civilisation. Rating: G

results.title: Briefing for health
results.brief_description: Indicates the dangers facing the female recruit when she joins the W.A.A.F. The ravages of venereal diseases are illustrated, with information on the avoidance of the disease and on measures to be taken if it is suspected that the disease has been contacted. No other credits available.

results.title: Brief encounter [study extract]
results.brief_description: An extract from “Brief encounter” directed by David Lean. An ordinary suburban housewife, and a young married doctor, meet casually, fall deeply in love, but realises family ties do not permit their passion so they part. In the extract Laura and Alec spend their last day together before he goes to South Africa. They part where they met - in the station buffet. Their last moments are shattered by the arrival of a talkative friend of Laura’s. In despair she almost commits suicide but reason prevails and she returns to her husband. The extract is dominated by the heavy atmosphere of the railway station, the emotional dialogue and the climax of the suicide attempt.

results.title: Brief encounter
results.creator_credit: David Lean, Noel Coward and Cineguild
results.brief_description: Dr. Alex Harvey (Trevor Howard) and Laura Jesson (Celia Johnson) meet at a railway station and fall in love. Married to other people in middle-class suburban England, they nevertheless maintain an acquaintanceship on her shopping trips to town which deepens into a friendship which blossoms into forbidden love. This is the original screen version of Noel Coward’s one act play, “Still Life”. Atmospherically directed by David Lean, “Brief Encounter” is an evergreen romance classic of post-war English cinema with seamless performances from the leading actors and an excellent music score borrowing heavily from Rachmaninoff. The screenplay was also written by Noel Coward.
